title: Court docs reveal Boris Johnson will send extension letter to EU by October 19

Boris Johnson will delay Brexit if he fails to strike a deal with Brussels, a court heard yesterday.

The Prime Minister is ready to execute a screeching U-turn and keep the UK in the EU after October 31, according to Government papers.

Extending Britain’s membership would deal a fresh hammer blow to the Tory leader’s trustworthiness after he spent months insisting we would leave on Halloween, “do or die”.

But court documents revealed he is poised to comply with the law and ask for an extension if he cannot agree a new pact with EU chiefs.

Downing Street refused to comment but claimed the UK would be leaving the EU on October 31.

In submissions to Scotland's Highest Court the government said that Johnson accepted that he was obliged to send a letter to the EU asking for a delay.

The legal action - led by businessman Vince Dale, SNP MP Joanna Cherry QC and Jolyon Maugham QC - will ask the court to require Mr Johnson to seek an extension to avoid leaving the EU without a deal.

Aidan O'Neill QC, who is representing the trio, told the court that submissions from the government revealed the prime minister "will send a letter... no later than 19 October" to the EU.

(Image: Sky News)

The bombshell documents come after the prime minister used his Tory conference speech on Wednesday to promise to "get Brexit done" by exit day, come what may.

He told delegates: "That is why we are coming out of the EU on October 31, come what may conference.

"Let’s get Brexit done. We can we must and we will, even though things have not been made easier by the surrender bill."

Downing Street refused to comment but claimed the UK would be leaving the EU on October 31.

Brexiteer Tory MP Steve Baker tweeted: “A source confirms all this means is that Government will obey the law.

“It does not mean we will extend.

“It does not mean we will stay in the EU beyond Oct 31. We will leave.”

The apparent contradiction suggests the PM could formally request an extension but plead with EU leaders not to grant it.

(Image: Twitter)

Or he could ask an ally to veto a delay.

Brexit Party leader Nigel Farage said: "Boris said we would leave by October 31st 'do or die'.

"Why does he keep saying things that are not true?"

The bombshell risks exploding the Conservative leader’s shaky authority after he vowed he would “rather be dead in a ditch” than plead for another delay to Article 50, the mechanism for leaving the bloc.

Under a law passed last month, the PM must seek an extension from Brussels if he is unable to get a withdrawal deal through Parliament by October 19.

Downing Street hopes final details can be thrashed out at a crunch summit on October 17-18.

But if there is no-deal, legislation known as the Benn Act – named after its architect, Labour MP Hilary Benn – means he must ask for a delay.

The PM controversially branded the law “the Surrender Act” and said it made negotiating more difficult.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

Until yesterday, Mr Johnson claimed the Government would obey the law – but also insisted he would never seek an extension.

Papers submitted to the Court of Session in Edinburgh suggest he has blinked and is ready to do just that.

Documents lodged with Scotland’s highest civil court outline that the PM would not attempt to frustrate the Benn Act.

Speaking at a press conference in Copenhagen alongside his Danish counterpart, Irish PM Leo Varadkar indicated he would back a further delay.

He said: “My preference is that we come to an agreement and that we have a deal by the middle of October.

“But if the UK government were to request an extension, of course we would consider it.

“But I think most EU countries would really only consider it for a good reason, and that reason would have to be put forward.

“But certainly an extension would be better than no-deal.”

The move came as the PM battled to save his Brexit blueprint.

His plan to avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland the Republic includes effectively leaving the province in the EU’s Single Market, but pulling it out of the Customs Union alongside the rest of the UK.

Customs checks will take place away from the 310-mile frontier.

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

There will be a crucial role for the Northern Ireland Assembly, which has not sat since the power-sharing executive collapsed in January 2017.

The Assembly would have to approve the plan every four years - potentially giving the Democratic Unionist Party a veto.

Northern Ireland Secretary Julian Smith was holding talks with provincial party leaders at Hillsborough Castle, Belfast, yesterday in a bid to rally support for the plan.

He also hoped to kick-start moves to restore the Assembly so it can give its approval.

Dublin has poured cold water on the PM’s plan.

Mr Johnson is due to meet Irish counterpart Leo Varadkar next week, as well as launching a whistle-stop tour of European capitals as he tries to win over EU leaders.

Dublin and Brussels have urged No10 to publish the full legal text of its proposals.

The document was handed to negotiators in secret on Wednesday.

But EU leaders want it made public.

No10 could agree if it means formal negotiations can quickly reopen.

A Downing Street spokeswoman said: “It’s something that we will consider.”

UK teams are ready to resume talks over the weekend - and the European Commission made clear time was tight.

Commission spokeswoman Natasha Bertaud said: “What we have always said is that every day counts, especially as we near the end of October.

“Technical-level meetings are currently ongoing in order to give the United Kingdom opportunity to present their proposals in more detail but no deadline has been set.”
description: The PM has said Britain would leave the EU "do or die" on October 31
